danfulea.math.numerical

Class Sorting

  • java.lang.Object
    • danfulea.math.numerical.Sorting

  • public class Sorting
extends java.lang.Object
    Sorting class
    Based on literature, including Numerical Recipes in C (Cambridge Univ.).
    Author:
    Dan Fulea, 10 OCT. 2006.

      Sorts an array arr[1..n] into ascending numerical order, by straight insertion, while making the corresponding rearrangement of the array brr[1..n].

    • Method Detail

      • piksrt

        public static void piksrt(int n,
                          double[] arr)
        Sorts an array arr[1..n] into ascending numerical order, by straight insertion. n is input; arr is replaced on output by its sorted rearrangement.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        arr - arr

      • piksr2

        public static void piksr2(int n,
                          double[] arr,
                          double[] brr)
        Sorts an array arr[1..n] into ascending numerical order, by straight insertion, while making the corresponding rearrangement of the array brr[1..n].
        Parameters:
        n - n
        arr - arr
        brr - brr

      • shell

        public static void shell(int n,
                         double[] a)
        Sorts an array a[] into ascending numerical order by Shell’s method (diminishing increment sort). a is replaced on output by its sorted rearrangement. Normally, the argument n should be set to the size of array a, but if n is smaller than this, then only the first n elements of a are sorted. This feature is used in selip.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        a - a

      • SWAP

        public static void SWAP(double a,
                        double b)
        SWAP two numbers of double type
        Parameters:
        a - a
        b - b

      • SWAP

        public static void SWAP(int a,
                        int b)
        SWAP two numbers of int type
        Parameters:
        a - a
        b - b

      • sort

        public static void sort(int n,
                        double[] arr)
        Sorts an array arr[1..n] into ascending numerical order using the Quicksort algorithm. n is input; arr is replaced on output by its sorted rearrangement.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        arr - arr

      • sort2

        public static void sort2(int n,
                         double[] arr,
                         double[] brr)
        Sorts an array arr[1..n] into ascending order using Quicksort, while making the corresponding rearrangement of the array brr[1..n]. Useful for sampling a coordinate system (we sort x-value and want y to be changed accordingly as they are pairs).
        Parameters:
        n - n
        arr - arr
        brr - brr

      • hpsort

        public static void hpsort(int n,
                          double[] ra)
        Sorts an array ra[1..n] into ascending numerical order using the Heapsort algorithm. n is input; ra is replaced on output by its sorted rearrangement.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        ra - ra

      • indexx

        public static void indexx(int n,
                          double[] arr,
                          int[] indx)
        Indexes an array arr[1..n], i.e., outputs the array indx[1..n] such that arr[indx[j]] is in ascending order for j = 1, 2, . . . ,N. The input quantities n and arr are not changed.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        arr - arr
        indx - indx

      • rank

        public static void rank(int n,
                        int[] indx,
                        int[] irank)
        Given indx[1..n] as output from the routine indexx, returns an array irank[1..n], the corresponding table of ranks.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        indx - indx
        irank - irank

      • select

        public static double select(int k,
                            int n,
                            double[] arr)
        Returns the kth smallest value in the array arr[1..n]. The input array will be rearranged to have this value in location arr[k], with all smaller elements moved to arr[1..k-1] (in arbitrary order) and all larger elements in arr[k+1..n] (also in arbitrary order).
        Parameters:
        k - k
        n - n
        arr - arr
        Returns:
        the result

      • selip

        public static double selip(int k,
                           int n,
                           double[] arr)
        Returns the kth smallest value in the array arr[1..n]. The input array is not altered.
        Parameters:
        k - k
        n - n
        arr - arr
        Returns:
        the result

      • hpsel

        public static void hpsel(int m,
                         int n,
                         double[] arr,
                         double[] heap)
        Returns in heap[1..m] the largest m elements of the array arr[1..n], with heap[1] guaranteed to be the the mth largest element. The array arr is not altered. For efficiency, this routine should be used only when m less or equal than n/2.
        Parameters:
        m - m
        n - n
        arr - arr
        heap - heap
